newsitem.title: CHINA: China to launch next satellite before end-1996.
newsitem.headline: China to launch next satellite before end-1996.

text.p: China plans to carry out its next satellite launch before the end of the year despite a failure over the weekend, a spokesman for the China Aerospace Corp said on Wednesday.
"The next launch will depend on the weather...and preparations," the spokesman said by telephone.

He said no launch contracts had yet been cancelled after the disclosure that a satellite launched on Sunday failed to reach its proper orbit. The cause of the failure was still under investigation, he said.

On Sunday, a domestic communications satellite, launched aboard a Long March 3 rocket from the Xichang space centre in southwest China, went into a lower orbit than planned and was unlikely to be salvaged.
Asked why announcement of the failure was delayed by one day, the spokesman said time was needed to determine if it had actually failed to go into proper orbit.
The Chinapac-7 satellite was built by Hughes Space and Communications Co of the United States, a unit of General Motors Corp.

It was launched for domestic television and telecommunications use by China Telecommunication Broadcasting Satellite Corp, which is under the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications. It had an insured value of $120 million.

It was the latest in a string of setbacks that have plagued China's space industry. An Intelsat satellite was destroyed in a spectacular explosion in February when a Long March 3B rocket veered wildly, seconds after lift-off from Xichang, killing six people, injuring 57 and destroying 80 homes.
In January 1995, a Long March rocket blew up, destroying the Apstar 2 satellite and killing six people.
